[]Author: Vic;
Rating: 5

Absolutely in love with this place. It is huge so I would recommend spending a day or two if you really wanna go through everything. wasn‚Äôt too crowded overall except around the Mona Lisa where it was a stampede. There is something for everyone here, it ranges in different time periods and art forms. I came from Canada to visit and got the membership which I would recommend considering it was almost the same price as single admission and the line was shorter.p

Author: Walt Bionik;
Rating: 5
When: 5 months ago
The best art museum in the world. The Mona Lisa may be on your bucket list, but please do yourself a favor and see the rest of the museum. There are many paintings that are breathtaking that do not get the attention because of the "Photo Op" paintings. Contrary to what I read, I did not have to wait in a long line. The Louvre is very easy to get to by Metro and easy to navigate. I'm American and it was my first time in Paris. I can't wait to visit again.

Author: Priya Indian Vlogger in Germany;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
There is no doubt that it is an absolute must visit for anyone who visits Paris. The place is the most beautiful museum of the whole world and houses a great deal of artworks, paintings and monuments. It is a real gem with lots of very high-end artworks. The quality of all sculptures is way too high as you can easily see and feel it. Mona Lisa is also in this museum. I was simply amazed at each and every part of this museum as it was full of history and has lots of very fine artworks around. It is very well organized and maintained and worth every penny. I would recommend to must visit it if you are going to Paris.

Author: Marinko Zubac;
Rating: 5
When: 9 months ago
The museum is amazing. We were the whole day in Louvre and still you have the impression that you could stay there forever. It's something you definitively should visit when in Paris. Buy your tickets online so you don't have to wait in queues for the entrance. The entrance to the museum is very simple. We waited for about 10 minutes to get through security. My suggestion is to get the Nintendo audio guide when visiting the Museum. It costs only 5 Eur and it helps a lot. The audio guide follows your location and helps to find around the museum. Its something like google maps for Louvre. When we were there Mona Lisa room was not too crowded so we had plenty of time to watch the painting. Do not search for souvenirs in the museum itself, you will have to go outside the museum in the direction of Metro station. There you will find the official Louvre Musem Shops.

Author: Jenny Fall;
Rating: 5

Visiting the Louvre is an amazing experience that will stay with you forever. There is so much history and beauty to absorb and admire. The building itself is exquisite along with the beautiful painted ceilings. Then, there is of course all of the art. Winged Victory, Venus Di Milo, and the Mona Lisa are just a few of the world's most famous works of art that are permanently on display at the Louvre.

[]Author: Mc Da;
Rating: 5

Lovely museum! There's loads of information to learn about chocolate, where it came from and how it is made. Beautiful exposition of chocolate cups (some of them are truly stunning), and also a bit of a history of chocolate in France. At the end there is demonstration where chocolate is made in front of your eyes, and you get to taste the delicious freshly made pralines. As you go through the museum, there's lots of opportunities to taste different types of chocolate too! And of course you can buy some more in the souvenir shop at the end. Really worth visiting!

Rating: 4

Nice museum, very friendly and helpful staff and some interesting exhibits. My kids and I took a workshop, which was fun and provided a lot of quite delicious homemade chocolate creations to take home. *One big suggestion for this museum, however: PLEASE add some serving pieces to all those samples of chocolate everywhere and to the workshop bowls! People are coming from all over the world, picking up viruses as they travel through Paris, and then sharing them with everyone else as they all reach into bowls. It's a recipe for passing colds, flu, and other nasty bugs. Other workshops we've taken also required everyone to wash their hands first. No one here seemed to care. Very surprising (and disheartening). Besides this, though, our trip to the museum was very enjoyable.

Name: Museum of the Art and History of Judaism
Last 5 Reviews:
[]Author: Dr Dorothy Lobel King;
Rating: 5
When: 6 months ago
Definitely worth seeing even if you‚Äôre not Jewish.

Author: Chaim Noy;
Rating: 3
When: a year ago
I want to say that I am a museum buff, and I visited many Jewish museums, both in Europe and North America. I expected more of this museum. It's a large museum with three floors of Jewish artifacts. However, it seems that there is something that repeats itself in the museum and also a quiet conventional: too many artifacts and too little narrative of the vibrant history of Jews in Paris and in France. When we visited, the Helena Rubinstein exhibition was open, and that was something else! Highly recommend. A big attraction and success for the museum, but also a clear contrast to the otherwise tired museum halls.

Author: Gregory Kantor;
Rating: 2
When: a year ago
I was disappointed with this museum, unfortunately. Instead of presenting a compelling narrative about Parisian/French Jews (as the museum's website essentially identifies as a primary goal), MAHJ is a rather disjointed collection of Judaica framed around holidays/rituals etc. Most of the museum's artifacts and artworks are only described on placards in French; the English audioguide provides good detail and context, but not on enough exhibits. The one positive surprise was the collection of several Chagall paintings. Overall, though, I think most foreign visitors will be disappointed.

Author: Andrew C. - My Inspire Project;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
Monsieur Alaia was not only the innovator in fashion but also had the vision to preserve the legacy and cultural values of fashion. He had collected numerous pieces from many masters in the past and had the opportunity to take over a vast collection from Balenciaga when the house shuttered. He realized the importance to continue the legacy and also to pass it towards the next generations. The foundation is located where he used to base and work, and it is the best place to understand his philosophy and works. Merci Beaucoup, monsieur Alaia, I have always been a big fan and will always be one for you and your devotion to our style and world. RIP!
